column1: In this video
column2: we are going to learn how to create a voice controlled lighting system that automatically turns on an LED when it detects sound in a dark environment.

column1: This project combines a sound sensor
column2: a photo resistor and an LED.

column1: To simulate a smart lighting control system similar to hallway or staircase lighting that turns on only when needed.
The photo resistor ensures that the LED does not turn on during daytime or when the light level is already bright
column2: which helps save energy.

column1: The sound sensor detects the volume of noise in the environment and compares it to a preset threshold.
When the sound is loud enough
column2: for example a clap or someone speaking
column3: the LED switches on for a few seconds and then turns off automatically.

column1: Let us understand how the code is built.
First we drag and place the basic setup.
Blocks for reading the photoresistor and controlling the LED's.
Next we add an if condition block to check the photo resistor value.
If the analog value is lower than a threshold such as 500
column2: meaning it is dark
column3: the program continues to the next condition.

column1: Inside the zip block.
We add another if condition to check the sound sensor reading.
If the sound value goes above 200
column2: meaning a detectable sound is made
column3: the LED turns on.

column1: Then we insert a delay of five seconds so the LED stays lit for a short duration before turning off.
Once the code is ready and uploaded
column2: we can test the system.

column1: If you make loud sounds under normal lighting conditions
column2: the LED will not turn on because the photo resistor detects brightness and blocks the signal.

column1: However
column2: if you cover the photo resistor to simulate darkness and then clap or speak loudly
column3: the LED lights up for five seconds and then turns off automatically.

column1: In this project we create an automatic CSI using a Control Board and a servo motor.
A seesaw normally moves up and down when children push with their feet
column2: but here the movement is controlled electronically.

column1: The servo motor is connected to pin 13 of the main board
column2: with its power and ground properly connected.

column1: When the program starts
column2: the board sends angle and delay commands to the servo motor.

column1: By changing the angle value
column2: the servo rotates in a specific direction and speed
column3: which makes one side of the seesaw rise while the other side falls.

column1: An angle close to 90 slows or stops the rotation
column2: while values lower or higher than 90 control the direction and speed.

column1: With the added delay
column2: the motion becomes smooth and continuous
column3: giving the seesaw A realistic up and down movement.

column1: This project helps students understand how servo motors work

column1: This rope skipping machine uses a joystick module
column2: a 360 servo motor
column3: and a passive buzzer to create an automatic skipping system.

column1: The joystick works using I2C communication and provides 2 analog values X&Y ranging from zero to 1023 along with a digital button output in the neutral position.
Both X&Y values are around 512.
The 360 servo motor is connected to pin D13.
And is controlled by changing its angle value.
When the servo angle is set to 90
column2: the motor stops rotating.

column1: If the angle is less than 90
column2: the servo rotates in One Direction and if it is greater than 90 it rotates in the opposite direction.

column1: By changing how far the value is from 90
column2: the speed of rotation can be increased or decreased.

column1: In the program
column2: the joystick values are continuously read inside a loop.

column1: If the X axis value is greater than 512
column2: the rope rotates in One Direction.

column1: If it is less than 512
column2: the rope rotates in the opposite direction.

column1: This allows the skipping direction and speed to be controlled smoothly using the joystick.
When the joystick button is pressed
column2: the passive buzzer plays a sound giving audio feedback to the user.

PWM pins are crucial for controlling devices that required a range of values instead of a simple on off state such as adjusting the brightness of an LED
column2: controlling the speed of a bio motor or creating analog like output for audio signals.

column1: The PWM pins can be identified.
By the tilt symbol marked next to pin number on the Arduino board.
As you can see we have a different symbols on our few digital pins like 356910 and 11.
Now what is PWM?
PWM stands for Pulse Width Modulation.
It is a method used by microcontroller to create an average.
Voltage that appears analog.
The idea is to turn a digital signal on and off repeatedly to generate a square wave by varying the proportion of time the signal is on versus off.
You can change the output also
column2: for example if the signal is on for 5060% of the time.

column1: And off for 50% of the time
column2: you get a 50% duty cycle
column3: which represent an average output voltage of about 2.5 Volt when the supply voltage is 5 Volt.

column1: If the duty cycle is 25%
column2: the average voltage would be approximately 1.25 V if the duty cycle is 75%.

column1: The average voltage would be about 3.75 Volt.
This technique allowed the Arduino to approximate analog output even though it is a digital device that can only output high 5 Volt or low 0 Volt signals.
Now how to use PWM pins on the Arduino Uno in the Arduino programming language you.
Can use with analog write function to generate a PWM signal on any of the PWM pins.
The analog write function take two parameters
column2: the pin number.

column2: where 0 represents 0 duty cycle and 25.

column1: Five represent 100% duty cycle.

Duty cycle means 0% duty cycle is always off and 100% duty cycle is always on.
We have various kinds of application of PWM pens.
The first one is light brightness control.
Using PWM pin you can control.
The brightness of an LED's.
The higher the duty cycle the brighter the LED will appear.
Motor speed control.
You can also use PWM pin to control the speed of bio motor.
By adjusting the duty cycle you can make the motor run slower or more faster.
Audio signal generation.
PWM can be used to create.
Found by generating various frequencies.
By changing the duty cycle and frequency you can create different audio tunes.
Servo motor control PWM pin can also use to control server motors which require specific PWM pins to set their positions.
